title: Enslaved people
common:
Introduction

We are all a unique species with a common origin that dates back hundreds of thousands of years (History Tracers, ). Despite this fundamental equality, there have been numerous instances of mistreatment among humans, including systems of slavery throughout different historical periods (Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies), as will be discussed in the following sections.

The Babylonian captivity

Estimating the beginning of the Babylonian Captivity is not an easy task (Britannica, T. Editors of Encyclopaedia, ; Horn, S. H, , pp. 13 - 15). According to Babylonian chronicles,

• Nebuchadnezzar left for Palestine (Hatti-land) in Kislev of his 7th regnal year (= to ), and that he seized "the city of Judah" (= Jerusalem) on Adar 2 (= ). Moreover, it is stated that on that day he "captured the king" and "appointed there a king of his own choice." This provides an exact date for the end of Jehoiachin's reign and the accession of Zedekiah (Horn, S. H, , pp. 20 - 21).

Based on these Babylonian Chronicles and Jewish texts, we conclude that Jerusalem fell in , with the deportation of the Jewish people occurring during this period (Horn, S. Mathematics in History

Mathematical limits (History Tracers, , Natural limits) help us estimate when certain events may have occurred.

In the previous paragraph, an interval of time was provided, indicating a minimum (initial value) and a maximum (final value), which delineate the possible period during which a specific event took place.

In everyday situations, many people prefer to work with exact values. However, since this is not always possible, it becomes necessary to use approximations, establishing limits within which the event could have occurred.

Slavery in the Iberian Peninsula

The practice of enslaving people and persecution in the Iberian Peninsula is ancient, as detailed by the Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies (Centre d'Estudis, Debats i Tertúlies). Various councils of Toledo describe the enslavement of Jews and the church's slaves (Montero, Pedro, ; CEDT, ESPAÑA VISIGODA: Los Concilios de Toledo sobre los esclavos de la Iglesia; y sobre la esclavitud y los judíos).
Centuries later, with the onset of Portuguese exploration, the papal bull "ROMANUS PONTIFEX" on granted Portugal the right to enslave people in the conquered lands:

• Nos, premissa omnia et singula debita meditatione pensantes, ac attendentes quod cum olim prefato Alfonso Regi quoscunque Sarracenos et paganos aliosque Christi inimicos ubicunque con­ stitutos, ac regna, ducatus, principatus, dominia, possessiones, et mobilia ac immobilia bona quecunque per eos detenta ac possessa invadendi, conquirendi, expugnandi, debellandi, et subjugandi, illorumque personas in perpetuam servitutem redigendi, ac regna, ducatus, comitatus, principatus, dominia, possessiones, et bona sibi et successoribus suis applicandi, appropriandi, ac in suos successorumque suorum usus et utilitatem convertendi, aliis nostris litteris

[translation: We, considering everything and every detail with due consideration, and paying attention to the fact that with the aforesaid King Alfonso, all the Muslims and heathens and other enemies of Christ wherever established, and kingdoms, principalities, principalities, dominions, possessions, and movable and immovable goods whatever held by them and to invade, conquer, conquer, defeat, and subjugate possessions, and to reduce their persons to perpetual servitude, and to apply and appropriate kingdoms, principalities, counties, principalities, dominions, possessions, and goods to themselves and their successors, and for the use and benefit of their own and their successors to convert, to our other letters]. The mentioned text was transcribed from Figure 1 lines 22 - 24:
Figure 1: Bula present in the Arquivo Nacional da Torre do Tombo, Lisboa, Portugal (Torre do Tombo, ).
This document laid the foundation for widespread persecution and enslavement in the Portuguese kingdom, as documented by Eduardo Bueno (Bueno, Eduardo, ).

Additional accounts of Slavery

The slavery system was also documented by Arab writers. Ibn Khaldūn, in his work, describes the people of Lamlam being invaded and enslaved: "... Negro people called Lamlam. They are unbelievers. They brand themselves on the face and temples. The people of Ghâmah and Takûr invade their country, capture them, and sell them to merchants who transport them to the Maghrib. There, they consitute the ordinary mass of slaves..." (Rosenthal, Franz, , pp. 118 - 119).

Indigenous enslavement

When Europeans arrived in America, indigenous peoples were initially recognized as laborers who could be enslaved. This is evident from various inventories (Arquivo Público do Estado de São Paulo).

Was there a slavery system in India?

Although slavery was practiced in various parts of the world, applying the concept directly to India is not straightforward, even considering the way of life of the Shudras (Karim Khan, Abdul, ; Patil, S., , pp. 33). There is no clear consensus on this subject, as S. Patil highlights in his work (Patil, S., , pp. 37 - 41, 46 - 47).
We must be careful when discussing beliefs to avoid causing offense. When we do not fully understand a belief and try to apply our own perspectives to others, we risk making mistakes.
